Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing Central Alaskan Precipitation Variability and Atmospheric Circulation during the Past Millennium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Large-scale atmospheric circulation systems affect the geographic distribution of precipitation in western North America, yet little is known about how these systems may have varied before the instrumental period of the last 150 years. The main goal of this project is to reconstruct the history of precipitation in Alaska during the last thousand years using ice core records of snow accumulation. The researchers plan to collect several new ice cores from the Mt. Hunter Plateau in the Alaska Range of Denali National Park and the new ice cores will be combined with an existing spatial array of ice cores in the region to map changes in the spatial patterns of precipitation. Because changes in atmospheric circulation patterns caused by ENSO and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) affect where the precipitation falls, this spatial array of ice cores will provide a record of how these larger scale climate systems have varied during the last thousand years. The project will focus on determining the differences in the precipitation patterns at the Little Ice Age (approximately 200 to 600 years ago) and Medieval Climate Anomaly (approximately 800 to 1,200 years ago).

This project will evaluate how changes in the climate state affect atmospheric circulation and precipitation. In addition the project includes K-12, undergraduate and graduate education activities, and, in conjunction with the National Park Service, the development of an interactive display showing the climate history of the region and the history of glacier advance and retreat in Denali National Park.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of our collaborative research, involving Dartmouth College, University of Maine, and University of New Hampshire, were to:

1) Produce the first high-resolution record of central Alaskan snow accumulation over the past millenium through the collection and geochemical analysis of new ice cores from Mt. Hunter plateau (3900 m elevation) in the Alaska Range (Denali National Park);

2) Evaluate to what extent the suite of North Pacific ice core accumulation records are representative of regional precipitation and atmospheric circulation patterns over the instrumental period; and

3) Compare model-based and proxy-based reconstructions of North Pacific climate during the Little Ice Age and Medieval Climatic Anomaly

 

Intellectual Merit:

The combination of high annual accumulation rate (~1.4 m water equivalent per year), mean annual temperature of -17°C, the collection of two parallel surface to bedrock ice cores, and high resolution glaciochemical analyses facilitate the development of an extraordinary, annually dated 1200 year long record.  This makes the Denali ice core record the best dated and longest annual resolved ice core record in the North Pacific region.

Analysis of this detailed ice core record has advanced knowledge of North Pacific paleoclimate in several ways:

1. Our results demonstrate that precipitation in the Alaska Range has reached unprecedented levels relative to the last 1200 years. Nearly all of this increase has occurred during the last two centuries in the winter, reflecting an intensification of the Aleutian Low to its strongest levels of the past millennium.

2. The Denali ice core melt layer stratigraphy provides a unique middle-tropospheric record of summertime temperature back 400 years (and we expect to extend this back 1200 years). The melt record has been calibrated to summer temperatures based on local and regional weather station analyses. The increase in melt production represents a summer warming of at least 1.92 +/- 0.31° C during the last 100 years, exceeding rates of temperature increase at most low elevation sites in Alaska. Our results show that rapid alpine warming has taken place in the Alaska Range for at least a century and that conditions in the tropical oceans contribute to this warming

3. We have combined the sodium record from the Denali ice core with an existing sodium record from a Mount Logan ice core (in the southwest Yukon territory) to created a composite North Pacific sodium ice core record that is calibrated and veritifed proxy for the wintertime (December to March) North Pacific Index (NPI). The composite NPI record indicates that the recent Aleutian Low intensification began circa 1741 and is unprecedented in magnitude and duration over the past millennium. North Pacific ice core snow accumulation and stable isotope records are consistent with this interpretation. The Aleutian Low intensification is associated with warming tropical Pacific sea surface temperatures, consistent with dynamic theory and instrumental correlations.

4. We have resolved, for the first time, anthropogenic Cu, Zn, and Cd in the North Pacific atmosphere. We also document clear evidence of pollution from Pb, As and Bi emissions in the Mt. Hunter core. Comparison of the Mt. Logan and Mt. Hunter records reveals that Asia is the dominant source of Mt. Logan pollution, while Mt. Hunter receives a mixture of Asian and North American pollution, with Asian pollution dominating in recent decades following the 1971 enactment of the Clean Air Act in the United States.

Broader Impacts

Our research project had broad benefits to society, including:

1. Serving as a highly successful platform for introducing graduate and undergraduate students to polar climate research on a socially relevant topic.  Over 30 students, including several women and underepresnted minorities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines from Dartmouth, University of Maine, and University of New Hampshire have taken part in field work with this project and many more have assisted with laboratory work and research.

 2. Developing novel, interactive, inquiry-based science curricula and exercises based on this research will enhance STEM offerings in K-12 schools in New England and Alaska.

 3. Improving the public's understanding of how recent changes in Alaskan temperature, precipitation, and atmospheric pollution compare with natural changes over the past millennium. Our datasets have shown that precipitation levels and atmospheric circulation in the Alaska Range are higher than they have been at any time during that last millennium. This finding has far reaching implications for our understanding of the climate system, and the North Pacific response to anthropogenic climate change. The summertime temperature and precipitation records have bearing on Alaska glaciers' contribution to global sea level rise, with implications for coastal community property and infrastructure, and consequently on public policy and resiliency planning.
